M.C. Escher was an artist that utilized mathematical principles. His Woodcut Circle Limit III (1959) is based on a tessellation using the (3,4,3,4,3,4) equation. Applying color and the theory of symmetry, we can determine the basic tile that Escher generated algebraically. Choosing a section of the basic tile, and assigning different colors to the three fish" we can adapt Escher's tessellation into a beautiful tiled pattern."

A soccer ball is not a perfect sphere -- it is in fact an approximation built from pentagons and hexagons. More precisely, there are two pentagons and a hexagon at each corner, or (5,5,6). There are many other ways of approximating the sphere with polygons. For example, the polyhedron (3,3,3,3,5), consisting of four triangles and a pentagon at each vertex is also a tessellation of a sphere. Viewing these deconstructions (a wireframe, just pentagons, and just triangles), the tessellation becomes a soccer ball reinvented.

column8: Felix Klein observed a tessellation in 1876 consisting of seven triangles at each vertex (3^7). This representation, titled Caught in a Dual Net (2008), superimposes Klein's observation in red over three heptagons at each vertex in purple, revealing a new tessellation (6,6,7). The turquoise heptagon and two hexagons are bounded by wire models of (3^7) and (7^3), with edges alternating between red and purple.

Sometimes the structure of a tessellation can be hidden. The core pattern of Sea Pearls (2011) consists of red and white circles of various sizes and color intensities that extend to the whole hyperbolic plane under symmetries of the original tessellation (7,7,7,7). The asymmetry of the pattern has the overall effect of breaking the original symmetry of the tessellation consisting of four heptagons at each vertex. The Sea of Pearls is a perfect example of how broken symmetry of one tessellation can complement the symmetries of the other.

The geometry and combinatorics behind the tessellations provide the framework for creative, artistic expression. Sometimes, the choice of a particular motif can alter or hide the mathematical structure, obscuring internal symmetries and how objects are positioned inside the graphic. This image, titled Eridanus after the Greek river god, has a pattern that exceeds the size of the tile, creating an overlapping, flowing effect reminiscent of a stream.

Sangaku are geometrical theorems or problems painted on wooden tablets. Placed as offerings at Shinto shrines or Buddhist temples during the Edo period by members of all social classes, the Sangaku was often presented as mathematical solutions to questions or challenges to congregants.  Seven towers (2011) features a tessellation of the hyperbolic plane and is inspired by Japanese pagodas. Shown in a classical black, red and white color scheme, the tessellation emphasizes a local 7-fold symmetry. The next tessellation uses a photo taken of the torii gates at Fushimi Inari, the head shrine of the god Inari in Kyoto, Japan using a pattern of 7 triangles and one of sangaku with 6 squares at a vertex.

Software Tess takes in a sequence of numbers, vertex symbol, and tries to construct a tessellation. The relation between the vertex symbols and tessellations is an intricate one! Sometimes the tessellation corresponding to a symbol is unique and sometimes not, like in our example (3,4,6,4) which corresponds to two different tilings. Although there are infinitely many tessellations of the hyperbolic plane, not all vertex configurations form a tessellation e.g. (3,5,4,5).

Beautiful ideas and objects in mathematics can also present an aesthetically appealing visualization. This tessellation (4,4,4,6), a disguised uniform object on the hyperbolic plane, is enriched with different tiles of various degrees of symmetry. The appeal of this kind of tessellation can be in the appreciation of the visual itself, a comprehension of the mathematics behind it, or the interplay of the two.

column8: Do mathematicians still use whiteboards to teach math? To answer your question, mathematicians still use whiteboards, although blackboards and chalk are preferred to do research. This hyperbolic and kaleidoscopic tessellation consists of six hexagons at each vertex, using the white board in a mathematics professor's office to fill in the tiles. The edges of the tiles in the tessellation act as mirrors to reflect the white board image.

Perspective matters nearly as much as position. In these images, a different polygon is placed at the center of the disk: triangle, square, hexagon. Regardless, these are all the exact same tessellation! Even stranger things happen when the tessellation is placed randomly inside the disk.

These networks and squares explore social network connections. Let's start with four friends at each corner of the square.  Each of these four friends have four other friends making their friendships overlap.  One of your friend's friends is also friends with a different friend creating a confusing social network to be encoded in a grid. If each friend has five friends, instead of four, the grid shape would not work, as we would need five connections. We would need even more room for a social network that branched six ways. Due to the number of connections, tessellations and the hyperbolic plane is perfect for drawing these social network connections.

Color is one method of tracking the symmetries of a tessellation. Different color schemes have a different visual impact, and arise different points of interest for the viewer. Which of these images present the same information?

Until Uranus was discovered in 1781, there were five known planets other than earth. Coincidentally, there are exactly five regular tessellations of the sphere, usually drawn as regular polyhedra. Johannes Kepler, the renowned 17th century scientist, wrote an entire book (Harmonices Mundi, 1619) arguing this was a physical law and connecting it to the theory of harmonics.

The simple and bold design of Lava (2012) takes the natural phenomenon to the hyperbolic plane. Columnar jointing appears when lava flows into the water, forming columns of polygonal cross-section forming a tessellation. Similar ideas have also inspired technological breakthroughs in engineering and biomedicine, such as negative stiffness honeycombs.

Knotted DNA, proteins, light, shoelaces- knots are important in our everyday lives and in science. Knotted tesslizations of the hyperbolic plane, ellation (2018) combines my research interest in knots with the visualizations of the hyperbolic space. The knot used as a tile was created using KnotPlot by R. Scharain then imported into the tessellation 5^7 created using software by M. Christersson.

Importance and universality of visualizations is best seen in ethnomathematics: the same mathematical ideas appear across cultures all over the world. Ornamental art, basketry  and textiles, one of the oldest implicit emanations of mathematical concepts, are used as an inspiration for the series of tessellations Something old, something new.
Breaking the symmetry!

This striking and radiant spiral image Dum Spiro Spero (2018) tells a story of hope. Constructed using an analogy of a spirograph in the hyperbolic plane, it  grows, unfolds and opens up into an invitation to bridge the gap between words and pictures, math and art...

The Roads (2018) is a triptych visualizing all the shortest roads between points in the hyperbolic plane represented in three different models: Poincare or Klein disk, and a Poincare halfplane model. Models work as lenses: lines representing roads look really different: sometimes they arestraight and sometimes parts of circles. The reason is equivalent to sending an airplane flying from Philadelphia to Munich via North Pole! No matter how they look they are always the shortest path (geodesic) even when they lead to infinity!

Watch how Fireworks (2018) from the Poincare Halfplane model where the horizontal bottom line represents infinity turn into a very different structure when viewed in disk models of the hyperbolic plane. Still they all have the spark!
